I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed results-
based loan to the People’s Republic of China (PRC) for the Air Quality Improvement in the Greater 
Beijing–Tianjin–Hebei (BTH) Region—Henan Cleaner Fuel Switch Investment Program.1 
 
2.  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) and the Government of the PRC agreed in 2015 to 
establish a multiyear lending program (2015–2020) that aims to reinforce government actions to 
reduce air pollution in the greater BTH region.2 The proposed program is the fifth loan under the 
multiyear lending program for air pollution reduction in the greater BTH region. It supports a switch 
to cleaner fuel, that is from coal to gas (natural gas and biogas) for residential, commercial, and 
industrial use to improve air quality in Henan Province.3 
 
II.  THE PROGRAM 
 
A.  Strategic Context 
 
3.  The greater BTH region is a major industrial and commercial zone, and generates about 
one-third of the PRC’s gross domestic product. The region’s gross domestic product has grown 
by about 8% annually between 2009 and 2018, but the heavy reliance on coal as the primary 
energy source for residential, commercial, and industrial purposes has resulted in serious and 
extensive air pollution. To address this, the PRC launched the first Comprehensive Action Plan 
for Air Pollution Prevention and Control 2013–2017, which aimed to improve air quality. The plan’s 
successful  implementation  has  reduced  concentrations  of  particulate  matter  less  than  2.5 
micrometer in diameter (PM2.5) by 39.6%, from 105 micrograms per cubic meter (μg/m3) in 2013 
to 64 μg/m3 in 2017.4 To further improve air quality, in June 2018 the central government issued 
the Three-Year Action Plan to Win Blue Sky War (2018–2020) to reduce emissions of nitrogen 
oxide (NOx) and sulfur dioxide (SO ) by over 15%, and emissions of PM  by over 18%, by 2020

(from 2015 levels). 5

populous and most coal-dependent province. It has good access to the major national natural gas 
transmission pipelines, but this has not been fully taken advantage of to reduce air pollution.6 In 
2018, coal provided about 72.0% of primary energy, compared with the national average of

5.  Henan Province’s policy framework (para. 4) seeks to reduce both high coal dependency 
and  air  pollution.  The  provincial  government’s  actions  focus  primarily  on  reducing  coal 
consumption through an annual limit, demolition of energy-inefficient coal-fired boilers, and 
promotion  of  natural  gas  and  other  cleaner  fuels.  As  a  result,  the  province’s  natural  gas 
consumption increased by 60.2% during 2014–2018. The primary driver was the increased supply 
of gas in urban areas, which accounted for 67.1% of total natural gas consumption in 2018.10 
Despite the rapid expansion in natural gas consumption in major urban centers, most of the 
population in semi-urban and rural areas in the province remains unserved, because of (i) the 
limited ability to pay for gas, and preference for traditional fuels among rural households; and (ii) 
the limited private and public investment appetite due to high costs of reaching geographically 
scattered populations in townships and villages.11 Another challenge is ensuring energy security, 
which requires decreased dependence on gas imports while sustaining a clean, long-term fuel 
supply. Biogas as an alternative domestic energy source has a large potential, because Henan 
Province is the largest producer of grain in the country. Production of biogas using crop waste is 
largely untapped, with biogas production below 1% of the province’s resource potential. 
 
B.  Program Rationale

medium- and long-term energy development plan,12 the Cleaner Fuel Switch Investment Program 
(2019–2030) was formulated to provide a clear expenditure and financing framework for access 
to gas in semi-urban and rural areas. This aims to establish a distributed gas supply network with

7.  Proposed results-based lending program. To ensure the long-term investment needed 
to support the switch from coal to gas is sustainably funded, the program will adopt ADB’s results-
based lending (RBL) modality during its initial stage. ADB’s RBL program will support program 
financing during 2019–2023 (the overall investment program is for 2019–2030). To address 
identified development challenges, the RBL program design incorporates lessons from past 
investments in natural gas supply networks in the province, including (i) reducing entry barriers 
for targeted customers by providing free connections; (ii) employing awareness campaigns for 
new customers to develop an awareness of safety issues and induce a switch away from 
traditional fuels; (iii) including biogas as a cleaner fuel source; and (iv) building institutional 
capacity to ensure sustainable investment and efficient operation, with private sector involvement 
to improve gas supply and customer service quality. The RBL modality is considered appropriate 
because it will (i) provide incentives to deliver on core results; (ii) enhance institutional and 
organizational capacity to leverage sustainable funding for subsequent long-term investment in 
the overall program; and (iii) lower the transaction costs of managing numerous small-scale 
activities and expenditures across the province using existing fiduciary and safeguard systems, 
which will be further reinforced with an agreed program action plan (PAP).13

active in supplying gas in urban areas, but the natural gas industry in the PRC has been largely 
dominated by state-owned enterprises which own most of the pipeline networks, storage facilities, 
and liquefied natural gas terminals; the existing industrial structure is hindering the response to 
the immediate need to reduce coal consumption to improve air quality. The government has 
initiated several reforms since 2018 that deregulate the natural gas sector in order to encourage 
private sector participation in upstream and downstream natural gas supply.14 The RBL program 
is aligned with ongoing sector deregulation in natural gas supply; private sector involvement will 
promote efficient gas delivery operations and services in semi-urban and rural areas, which is a 
difficult market segment for the private sector to tackle alone. A partnership with a private 
company was arranged to undertake the Cleaner Fuel Switch Investment Program. A special 
purpose vehicle—the Henan Yu-Tian New Energy Co. Ltd. (YTNE)15—was established as a joint 
venture project company between the Zhongyuan Yuzi Investment Holding Group (ZYIG), a

9.  ADB’s value addition. ADB financing using the RBL program modality will add substantial 
value by setting up a framework for sustainable implementation of the overall investment program 
and (i) providing (a) comprehensive support for behavioral changes in energy use through 
awareness campaigns to use gas, with particular attention on gender; and (b) cost reductions 
through no-cost gas connections for rural customers to lower social disparities in gas use; (ii) 
facilitating technology adoption for biogas production using the dry fermentation process, which 
is the first application in piped biogas supply in the PRC; and (iii) demonstrating a sustainable 
business model with private sector involvement in gas supply in semi-urban and rural areas, 
through capacity enhancement of the program implementing agencies with respect to corporate 
governance, financial management, environmental and social safeguards, procurement and 
anticorruption, and gender development. The RBL program provides a holistic solution to reducing 
development barriers to gas access in semi-urban and rural areas of the province. The lessons 
and experience from the RBL program are expected to be disseminated to other provinces in the 
greater BTH region that face similar challenges.18 The business model can also be replicated in 
other countries for a sustainable cleaner fuel switch to improve air quality. 
 
10.  The RBL program is fully aligned with the priorities of broadening the response to climate 
change and strengthening environmental sustainability in ADB’s country partnership strategy for 
the PRC, 2016–2020.19 It will support key strategic pillars of ADB’s Strategy 2030: (i) tackling 
climate  change,  building  climate  and  disaster  resilience,  and  enhancing  environmental 
sustainability  by  accelerating  low  greenhouse  gas  emissions  development  and  ensuring 
environmental sustainability through actions for expansion of natural gas use and development 
of bioenergy to build low carbon energy system in the PRC and thereby support its Nationally 
Determined Contributions;20 (ii) strengthening governance and institutional capacity by providing 
inclusive gas service with greater engagement of the private sector; and (iii) accelerating progress 
in achieving gender equality through gender mainstreaming activities.21 The RBL program will 
also  contribute  to  Sustainable  Development  Goal  7 (Ensure  access  to  affordable, reliable, 
sustainable, and modern energy for all) by providing affordable access to cleaner fuels in rural 
areas.

D.  Program Results 
 
12.  The RBL program’s impact will be air quality improved, with a switch in fuel from coal to 
gas aligned with the Henan Province medium- and long-term energy development plan (2012–
2030) (footnote 12). The outcome will be increased use of cleaner fuels by residential, commercial, 
and industrial customers in Henan Province (disbursement-linked indicators [DLIs] 1 and 2).22 
Institutional capacity enhancement under the RBL program will also lay the foundation to enable 
CNY 915 million of commercial financing (DLI 3), which will sustain investments under the overall 
program till 2030. The RBL program will have four outputs. 
 
13.  Output 1: Gas network system expanded. The RBL will develop a distributed gas 
system including a 26,880 kilometer (km) distribution network (DLI 4), and 12 gas stations (DLI 
5), thereby replacing the old coal-burning facilities. To address affordability concerns for rural

consumers, the RBL program will offer (i) end pipe connections at no cost; and (ii) an installment 
payment scheme to help purchase gas appliances, such as cooking stoves and heaters. 
 
14.  Output 2: Alternative clean fuel developed. The RBL program will develop a pilot biogas 
plant with an annual production capacity of 17 million Nm3 using the dry anaerobic fermentation 
process with agricultural waste to supplement natural gas in the future (DLI 6). The pilot plant will 
be the first utility-scale dry fermentation technology application for piped gas supply in the PRC, 
producing high-quality biomethane, which meets the PRC natural gas regulation standards. 
 
15.  Output 3: Cleaner fuel use awareness enhanced. The RBL program will help change 
the use of traditional energy by consumers, and enhance awareness regarding the use of cleaner 
fuels, and gas safety. It targets greater participation by female customers (at least 50% of 
participants) in the cleaner fuel awareness campaign that includes the benefit of gas for cooking 
and heating, the use of gas appliances, and safety of gas use. Continuous implementation of the 
awareness campaign will be essential to meet increased gas connection and consumption targets 
under the RBL program; at least 500 awareness campaigns will be convened throughout the 
program implementation period (DLI 7). 
 
16.  Output 4: Institutional and organizational capacity enhanced. The RBL program will 
support institutional and organizational capacity enhancement of ZYIG and YTNE to sustain 
overall program implementation, including after completion of the RBL program (DLI 8). This 
includes (i) developing an integrated enterprise resource planning and management system; (ii) 
strengthening corporate governance and management systems in financial and risk control, and 
environment  and  social  safeguard  management;  (iii)  expanding  fund-raising  capacity  and 
financing avenues for commercial borrowing; and (iv) increasing staff resources to ensure sound 
program implementation, with a gender balance target of increasing the proportion of female staff 
members, from 15% in 2018 to 30% by 2022. 
 
17.  Eight DLIs were selected to effectively promote the use of cleaner fuels through the 
development of the gas infrastructure; technology development through the use of advanced 
biogas fermentation technology; private sector involvement for efficient service delivery and 
sustainable funding; and behavioral changes among end-users, with particular attention on 
gender. The program is projected to reach a total of 1.2 million customers, with gas consumption 
of 316.63 million m3 per year. The RBL program is focused on core results; therefore, 55% of the 
total ADB loan amount is allocated to DLIs 1, 2, and 3. DLIs and disbursement allocation are

III.  SUMMARY OF ASSESSMENTS 
 
A.  Program Technical Assessments 
 
24.  The RBL program’s technical assessment indicates that the design of gas networks and 
gas stations fully complied with the national construction standards, and the associated cost 
estimate reflects the actual construction cost from natural gas supply projects implemented by 
CTLG. The biogas dry fermentation technology is proven in Europe but this will be the first 
application to piped gas supply in the PRC. The biogas design fully meets international standards 
and the estimated capital cost is the range of international costs. The first-of-its-kind technology 
risk in the PRC can be controlled by engaging an experienced international technology supplier. 
The overall gas safety standard for construction and operation is in accordance with natural gas 
safety regulations and guidelines in the PRC, which are as stringent as in the United States and

Europe.24 The gas facilities are designed to detect possible gas leakage at the end-users’ meters, 
distribution networks, and gas stations. YTNE is also aligned with the operational safety code of 
CTLG, which is compliant with international best practice. 
 
25.  The RBL program’s scope is considered appropriate to help sustainably implement the 
overall program. The overall cleaner fuel switch program adopts a phased approach with learning-
by-doing practices to construct and expand the gas supply networks. The RBL program aims to 
support the initial stage of the overall program to build practical capacity and knowledge to achieve 
the overarching program targets until 2030. Based on successful implementation of the RBL 
program, the overall program is expected to be implemented with additional commercial financing 
and  private  sector  involvement,  which  is  consistent  with  the  PRC’s  ongoing  natural  gas 
deregulation policy (para. 8). The RBL program’s financial and economic assessments found the 
program  to  be  financially  viable  and  economically  sustainable.25 The  institutional  financial 
performance of YTNE and ZYIG are projected to remain sound under the overall program. 
 
26.  The RBL program is classified effective gender mainstreaming. The gender analysis 
indicates women in the project area are largely responsible for household energy use for heating, 
cooking, and heating water for bathing children and elderly. These activities can be time intensive, 
particularly for the poorest households that still use coal or firewood. While they are supportive of 
the introduction of cleaner, faster, and more convenient fuels, women in the project sites want to 
know more about how to safely use non-traditional fuel. Changing traditional fuel use behavior 
among the targeted population in townships and villages is a challenge to achieving the intended 
results. Cleaner fuel awareness campaigns under the RBL program will support a change to gas 
use among end-users and will involve the participation of women (at least 50% of participants) in 
the campaigns, which will focus on the benefits of gas for cooking and heating, and safe usage 
of gas and gas appliances.26 The campaign will be undertaken on an ongoing basis, with at least 
500 events throughout the implementation period to ensure that a critical mass of users is reached 
and that connection and consumption targets under the RBL program are met. In addition, the 
share of female staff in YTNE will be doubled, from 15% in 2019 to 30% in 2022.

metadata.Subject: The Asian Development Bank (ADB) and the Government of the PRC agreed in 2015 to establish a multiyear lending program (2015–2020) that aims to reinforce government actions to reduce air pollution in the greater Beijing–Tianjin–Hebei (BTH) Region. The program is the fifth loan under the multiyear lending program for air pollution reduction in the greater BTH region. It supports a switch to cleaner fuel, that is from coal to gas (natural gas and biogas) for residential, commercial, and industrial use to improve air quality in Henan Province.
